L.H.
CRECCA
(32)

Installment Plan Adopted
On Payment Of Class
Dues
Senior dues were reduced to
twenty dollars at a meeting last
Thursday of senior class officials, it
was disclosed by Bill Reid, president
of the Senior Class. If dues are
not paid by Easter, they will be
raised to $23.50.
This action was taken as a result
of constant pressure from University authorities and complaints by
Seniors that the former twenty-five
dollar fee was a drain on their financial resources.
What Senior Gets

In return for the payment of dues,
each senior will receive two copies
of the 1933 Hullabaloo, one ticket to
the Senior Banquet, one ticket to
the Third Cotillion, and one ticket
for June Week activities.
Every senior will be presented
with a partial payment card which
will be a receipt for his payments.
He may pay his installments to any
class officer or to Bill Triplett at the
"Barn" on any day of the week between noon and 3 p. m.
"If every man will pay a small
amount each week, his dues will be
paid by Easter, thereby cutting down
the large drain on his finances when
he pays the total amount at once",
Reid declared in his statement.

bers of the teachers' college from campus organizations. The justification lies
in the lone facts that the College for
Teachers is not officially regarded as a
part of the undergraduate department in
the University, and that members of that
school do not pay the student activities
fee which aids in supporting campus activitie.
The S. A. C. is composed of delegates
from the activities in the three exclusively
male undergraduate schools-the A. B.,
engineering, and business. These delegates govern the activities with funds
made available from the ten-dollar fee
required of students in the three undergraduate schools.
In ridiculing the motion passed last
year stating that no women will in the
future be permitted to hold office or membership in campus activities governed by
the S. A. C., this paper last April said:
"That activity-governing body must pass
a motion which will exclude all members
of the College for Teachers from undergraduate activities and define an undergraduate eligible for membership as any
student of good standing in the College of
Arts and Sciences, School of Engineering,
and School of Business Economics."
The reasons for including the second
and third points of the motion now before
the Council are obvious.
We see no reason why the S. A. C.
should not definitely define eligibility in
campus activities. We hope that the motion will be passed.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1932

The Thirtieth Classic
CONCLUDING a not-too-brilliant
season, the Johns Hopkins eleven will
trot out on the Stadium gridiron Thanksgiving Day to clash with its ancient and
traditional rival, University of Maryland.
We make no predictions as to the results of the football tussle. But we do
wish the Jays the best of luck in the
annual classic.
This year's Hopkins-Maryland game
marks the thirtieth meeting on the gridiron of the two universities. In each
meet there has existed sportsmanship and
friendship, which, again this year, will
be carried into every phase of the annual
game on Thursday. No matter who wins,
the game will carry the thrills and color
that accompanies the Terrapin-Jay clash
on Turkey Day.
In speaking of athletic relations between the two institutions, Curly Byrd,
Maryland coach, in a letter said: "Certainly as long as I have anything to do
with the administration of affairs in the
University of Maryland, the cordial cooperation and pleasant friendship that now
exist between the two universities will
be fostered to the limit of my ability."
There is no possible denial of the fact
that there is an agreeable, friendly spirit
existing between the Hopkins and Maryland. That spirit will manifest itself in
the game on Thursday.
We sincerely hope, however, that the
students' spirit will not reach such a degree of overexuberance that property will
be marred and destroyed in the pre-game
demonstrations by members of both
schools. We call to the attention of the
Hopkins men the fact that last year some
deplorable things occurred in connection
with these demonstrations. We implore
that they hold their enthusiasm within
gentlemanly bounds. Games are not won
by marking up and destroying property
during pre-game parades.

Pass The Motion
THE motion before the Student Activities Council is of vital importance and
must be adopted by that body. It is sound
and logical.
It calls for these three vital things: (1)
that students in only the College of Arts
and Sciences, School of Engineering, and
School of Business Economics shall be
eligible for offices and membership in
activities represented in the Student Activities Council; (2) that a New Plan
student can be eligible for participation
in-these activities until the conclusion of
what would be his fourth year of undergraduate residence; (3) that any member
of the three undergraduate schools who is
expelled from the University by action of
Student Council or University officials
shall automatically lose any post held in
any activity.
This ruling, if passed, will exclude all
members of the College for Teachers from
membership in any activity represented
on the Student Activities Council. Despite
what protest may be made against that

V IIIIEWS

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.

With the advent of Thanksgiving
week, with its numerous games,
dances and gala affairs in general,
Baltimore theatrical producers are
doing themselves proud to present
one of the finest groups of topnotch
programs that have graced the old
city for a long, long time.
Florenz Ziegfeld that genius of
the American stage, lives again at
Ford's this week, where his great
success of three years back, Show
Boat, is making that old playhouse
gay with lovely music and more
lovely voices.
Charming Operetta

Generally conceded by 1 eading
critics as being one of the master
showman's finest vehicles, its run of
one week at Ford's will afford campus playgoers their last chance of
seeing and hearing one of the most
charming operettas of the present
day. If you have never seen it, don't
miss this last opportunity.
Motors are roaring down at the
Keith's, where the valiant heroes of
the skyways are brought out in all
their glory in the thrilling film epic,
Air Mail.
Fancy Stunting

It begins with a crash and ends
with a smash, and in between are
sandwiched seven reels of some of
the best plane and fancy stunting
that has appeared since Wings.
If you like a fast-moving tale well
told, you won't be sorry at having
chosen Keith's. It's good.
Once more Hollywood has dipped
into the realms of literature to
snatch the plot for a stirring picture,
and when it dramatized Tess Of

The Storm Country, the current attraction at the New, it did a very
good piece of work indeed.
Filmed against the picturesque
background of the Maine coast, the
action of the plot proceeds with a
rapidity worthy of the most bloodcurdling of the old-time melodramas, and anyone who comes
away without having received his
full quota of shakes and shiverswell, just hasn't any in his makeup.
Witty Rendition

An all-talking, German version
of that immortal masterpiece, The
Beggar's Opera, opened at the Europa Theater yesterday, and bids
fair to give that house one of the
most successful weeks of the fall
season.
It is a modernized version of the
famous old play, with a musical
score by the rising young German
composer, Kurt Weil, and in its
skillful combination of the best of
the old world with the bright wit of
the new, it is truly one of the year's
unusual pictures.
Aeroplane Journey

On the same bill, Lowell Thomas, noted globe trotter for The Literary Digest, takes us on a thrilling
aeroplane journey in a fascinating
film record of true adventure,
Wings Over The Andes. From beginning to end it is a great show.
And, by the way, have you heard
of the girl whot had an extemporaneous complexion-she made it up
Which goes
as she went along?
with that old song favorite:
"Orange Juice Sorry That You
Made Me Cry?"

Maya Club In Rowland

Behind the doors of the Maya
Club, located on the top floor of
Rowland Hall, there is the largest
colection of Maya documents and
manuscripts in the world, as well
as countless maps and photographs pertaining to the subject
of Maya culture.
When Dr. Gates first started
his research he was faced with
almost a sheer stone wall, for
there was little or no work on the
subject at the time he began his
investigations. The only sources
from which he could gather material for his investigation, were
the monuments and temples scattered throughout Yucatan and
Guatemala, which bore pictographs and hieroglyhics and a
few manuscripts, which the Spanish invaders took back to Europe
with them, as souvenirs. It took
years of constant alertness and
study to collect these sources together, but at last Dr. Gates and
the Maya society have in their
possession, over one-half of all the
original Mayan manuscripts as yet
discovered, as well as photostatic
copies of nearly all the rest.
Cipher Elusive
Even with this huge amount of
reference and data, it has been no
easy job to decipher any of the
glyphs, for there has been no key
found that forms a cipher for all of
them, it was said the vast amount
of knowledge that Dr. Gate has
required has been as a reuslt of
long and patient methods, which
involved classification, indexing
and cross-indexing.

It haunted clerks
for generations
"The first of the month" used to be a time of
feverish activity for ledger clerks. But the Bell
System accounting staff - breaking away from
tradition -simplified the keeping of accounts and
rendering of monthly statements to customers.
They applied a modern system of rotation billing to the telephone business which now spreads
this work evenly throughout the month. In cooperation with manufacturers, they devised special
typewriters and bookkeeping machines. Thus
they did away with inefficient rush and achieved
greater accuracy, speed and neatness.
This is but one example of a point of view found
throughout the Bell System. Even long accepted
routine is constantly studied- it's always worth
looking for the more efficient way!

DR. RAY VAN ORMAN

"FOUR HORSEMEN"
SCORE VICTORY FOR
JAY HARRIERS, 19-37

Hopkins Losses Less

Hopkins did not suffer so much
this year from the loss of veteran
material. In fact, with the exception of ex-Captain Helm, Bialosworske, and Bill Weitzel, all men
returned for the present campaign.
Thus the Jays have had a good
chance to develop a potential team.
However, certain obstacles did
confront Coach Van Orman which
later proved a severe handicap. In
the first place, the team was affected
by injuries. Throughout the season various varsity members were
either temporarily or permanently
disabled. Included among the injured were Triplett, Ives, Berger,
and several reserves.
As a result, the morale of the
team was broken down considerably. Perhaps this factor alone
might explain the meagre performances that the Jays have been giving in the last few games.
At present, however, the squad is
in an excellent mental state. The
spirit infused by the oncoming tussle and the smooth functioning of
the varsity in its practice sessions
have aided considerably. Especially
those new trick plays that the coach
has up his sleeve have been clicking
well.

Furst, Holtzman, King, And
Packard Take Early
Lead
With the "Four Horsemen" of the
cross-country team in the lead, the
Hopkins harriers defeated the Haverford squad last week, 19-37.
Furst, Holtzman, King, and Packard took the lead from the first and
never relinquished it. They all
crossed the finish line at the same
time.
Successful Season

This year has been one of the
most successful cross-country seasons, the Blue Jays having triumphed in all of their meets except
that with University of Virginia.
After opening the season with a
brilliant victory over Dickinson
College, the Black and Blue squad
lost its meet to Virginia, 21-37.
Fast Race

Running one of the fastest races
ever run on the five-mile course at
St. John's College, the team defeated the Johnnies by the score of
27-28.
The order of the finish in the
Haverford meet was:
King, Hopkins
Furst, Hopkins
Packard, Hopkins
Holtzman, Hopkins
Bodine, Haverford
Vance, Haverford
Mechling, Haverford
Scattergood, Haverford
Brown, Hopkins
Cornman, Hopkins

Four Hopkins Seniors To End
Football Careers At Stadium

Simultaneously with the closing
of the Hopkins football season at
the stadium Thursday, the careers of
four Blue Jay varsity football players will come to an end.
These seniors who will sport their
gridiron togs for the last time
Thursday are Paul Berger, Bill
Reid, Neil Sigler, and Bill Triplett.
Berger Injured

Paul Berger was a regular tackle
on the Black and Blue team this
year until be tore several ligaments
in his leg in the game against
Swarthmore and was forced to retire for the season. He has been
playing football for Hopkins for the
past three seasons. In his first and
second seasons Berger was a substitute lineman. This season, however,
he developed into a regular tackle
and was considered one of the best
linemen in the state prior to his injury.

Although the date

tation of the medal which Dr.
Kent R. Greenfield is to receive
from the Italian government is
yet uncertain, a description of the
medal has been obtained. The
medal bears on the reverse side
the head of the goddess Roma
while on the obverse side Romulus
and Remus are represented. It is
suspended from a ribbon made in
th Italian colors.
Dr. Mario Carosi, the Royal
Italian Consul, recommended Dr.
Greenfield for the honor in recognition of his work in bringing out
the merits of Italian culture. Dr.
Cams said that he had recommended Dr. Greenfield (who is at
present professor of modern
European history at the Hopkins) because of the latter's great
interest in the work over a period
of years. Dr. Carosi also said that
he felt honored to have been able
to recommend Dr. Greenfield.

of this year, but since the loss of
Berger he has played almost regularly.

Featuring Joe Sanders and his
Original Nighthawks, the First Cotillion will be held at the Alcazar on
Thanksgiving night with Miss Elizabeth Campbell Young, debutante
daughter of Dr. Hugh H. Young,
clinical professor of urology at the
Johns Hopkins School of Medicine,
as the guest of honor.
Under the leadership of Jerome
Toohey, the Cotillion Board has arranged a program that is said to be
the most elaborate ever presented
at a function under the sponsorship
of the university. The entire Alcazar has been taken over for the
affair.
Group Boxes Offered

Dancing, which starts at 10 p. m.,
will be in the main ballroom. The
Blue Room is to be furnished with
soft lights, deep chairs, and thick
rugs. Tables will be placed in the
gymnasium, and ginger-ale, fruit
punch, cracked-ice, and coffee will
be served at nominal charges.
As previously announced, separate boxes will be offered to any
groups or fraternity represented by
a sufficient number of members.
The Grand March which will
start at 11.30, will be led by Jerome
Toohey and Miss Young. At its conclusion, flowers will be presented to
the guest of honor.
It is rumored that, after the presentation of the flowers a special
entertainment will be given by several out-of-town debutantes. Specific plans could not be learned but
something very unusual is hinted.
Dancing will then be resumed, continuing until 3 a. m.

Allardyce Nicoll To
Talk On Kenelm
Digby,Nov.29
Allardyce Nicoll, professor of
English language and literature in
the University of London, will deliver the eleventh annual public lecture of the Tudor and Stuart Literary Club of the Johns Hopkins
University, on November 29, at 5
o'clock in the Great Hall of Levering.
His subject will be "Kenelm
Digby, Poet, Philosopher, and Pirate". Digby was a swashbuckling
cavalier of the time of Raleigh and
"Good Queen Bess."

To Visit Colleges In Northern and Southern
States
FROSH-SOPH DEBATE
SCHEDULED DEC. 8
Final Teams And Topics
To Be Announced
Soon
Canceling the proposed debate
with Oxford, due to the expense
which it would entail, the debating
association has announced that it intends taking two trips, one north and
one south during the spring semester, debating colleges in those regions.
Members of the association believed that, instead of expending a
large sum of money for only one
debate, much more advantage would
be derived from the two trips. It
is planned to make the northern trip
cover New England and New York,
while the southern one will include
Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee.
Each of the journeys will extend
over a period of one week, stops
being made every other night at
colleges en route.

Popular Lecturer

Professor Nicoll is giving a series
of lectures in this country and will
visit Baltimore after a western tour.
He will speak in various colleges in
the South after he leaves here.
He was chosen as the G. A. Clark
Scholar in English Literature. He
was also a lecturer at Longborough
College in English Literature before
he received his professorship.

Installment Plan Adopted
On Payment Of Class
Dues
Senior dues were reduced to
twenty dollars at a meeting last
Thursday of senior class officials, it
was disclosed by Bill Reid, president
of the Senior Class. If dues are
not paid by Easter, they will be
raised to $23.50.
This action was taken as a result
of constant pressure from University authorities and complaints by
Seniors that the former twenty-five
dollar fee was a drain on their financial resources.
What Senior Gets

In return for the payment of dues,
each senior will receive two copies
of the 1933 Hullabaloo, one ticket to
the Senior Banquet, one ticket to
the Third Cotillion, and one ticket
for June Week activities.
Every senior will be presented
with a partial payment card which
will be a receipt for his payments.
He may pay his installments to any
class officer or to Bill Triplett at the
"Barn" on any day of the week between noon and 3 p. m.
"If every man will pay a small
amount each week, his dues will be
paid by Easter, thereby cutting down
the large drain on his finances when
he pays the total amount at once",
Reid declared in his statement.

bers of the teachers' college from campus organizations. The justification lies
in the lone facts that the College for
Teachers is not officially regarded as a
part of the undergraduate department in
the University, and that members of that
school do not pay the student activities
fee which aids in supporting campus activitie.
The S. A. C. is composed of delegates
from the activities in the three exclusively
male undergraduate schools-the A. B.,
engineering, and business. These delegates govern the activities with funds
made available from the ten-dollar fee
required of students in the three undergraduate schools.
In ridiculing the motion passed last
year stating that no women will in the
future be permitted to hold office or membership in campus activities governed by
the S. A. C., this paper last April said:
"That activity-governing body must pass
a motion which will exclude all members
of the College for Teachers from undergraduate activities and define an undergraduate eligible for membership as any
student of good standing in the College of
Arts and Sciences, School of Engineering,
and School of Business Economics."
The reasons for including the second
and third points of the motion now before
the Council are obvious.
We see no reason why the S. A. C.
should not definitely define eligibility in
campus activities. We hope that the motion will be passed.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1932

The Thirtieth Classic
CONCLUDING a not-too-brilliant
season, the Johns Hopkins eleven will
trot out on the Stadium gridiron Thanksgiving Day to clash with its ancient and
traditional rival, University of Maryland.
We make no predictions as to the results of the football tussle. But we do
wish the Jays the best of luck in the
annual classic.
This year's Hopkins-Maryland game
marks the thirtieth meeting on the gridiron of the two universities. In each
meet there has existed sportsmanship and
friendship, which, again this year, will
be carried into every phase of the annual
game on Thursday. No matter who wins,
the game will carry the thrills and color
that accompanies the Terrapin-Jay clash
on Turkey Day.
In speaking of athletic relations between the two institutions, Curly Byrd,
Maryland coach, in a letter said: "Certainly as long as I have anything to do
with the administration of affairs in the
University of Maryland, the cordial cooperation and pleasant friendship that now
exist between the two universities will
be fostered to the limit of my ability."
There is no possible denial of the fact
that there is an agreeable, friendly spirit
existing between the Hopkins and Maryland. That spirit will manifest itself in
the game on Thursday.
We sincerely hope, however, that the
students' spirit will not reach such a degree of overexuberance that property will
be marred and destroyed in the pre-game
demonstrations by members of both
schools. We call to the attention of the
Hopkins men the fact that last year some
deplorable things occurred in connection
with these demonstrations. We implore
that they hold their enthusiasm within
gentlemanly bounds. Games are not won
by marking up and destroying property
during pre-game parades.

Pass The Motion
THE motion before the Student Activities Council is of vital importance and
must be adopted by that body. It is sound
and logical.
It calls for these three vital things: (1)
that students in only the College of Arts
and Sciences, School of Engineering, and
School of Business Economics shall be
eligible for offices and membership in
activities represented in the Student Activities Council; (2) that a New Plan
student can be eligible for participation
in-these activities until the conclusion of
what would be his fourth year of undergraduate residence; (3) that any member
of the three undergraduate schools who is
expelled from the University by action of
Student Council or University officials
shall automatically lose any post held in
any activity.
This ruling, if passed, will exclude all
members of the College for Teachers from
membership in any activity represented
on the Student Activities Council. Despite
what protest may be made against that

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.

With the advent of Thanksgiving
week, with its numerous games,
dances and gala affairs in general,
Baltimore theatrical producers are
doing themselves proud to present
one of the finest groups of topnotch
programs that have graced the old
city for a long, long time.
Florenz Ziegfeld that genius of
the American stage, lives again at
Ford's this week, where his great
success of three years back, Show
Boat, is making that old playhouse
gay with lovely music and more
lovely voices.
Charming Operetta

Generally conceded by 1 eading
critics as being one of the master
showman's finest vehicles, its run of
one week at Ford's will afford campus playgoers their last chance of
seeing and hearing one of the most
charming operettas of the present
day. If you have never seen it, don't
miss this last opportunity.
Motors are roaring down at the
Keith's, where the valiant heroes of
the skyways are brought out in all
their glory in the thrilling film epic,
Air Mail.
Fancy Stunting

It begins with a crash and ends
with a smash, and in between are
sandwiched seven reels of some of
the best plane and fancy stunting
that has appeared since Wings.
If you like a fast-moving tale well
told, you won't be sorry at having
chosen Keith's. It's good.
Once more Hollywood has dipped
into the realms of literature to
snatch the plot for a stirring picture,
and when it dramatized Tess Of

The Storm Country, the current attraction at the New, it did a very
good piece of work indeed.
Filmed against the picturesque
background of the Maine coast, the
action of the plot proceeds with a
rapidity worthy of the most bloodcurdling of the old-time melodramas, and anyone who comes
away without having received his
full quota of shakes and shiverswell, just hasn't any in his makeup.
Witty Rendition

An all-talking, German version
of that immortal masterpiece, The
Beggar's Opera, opened at the Europa Theater yesterday, and bids
fair to give that house one of the
most successful weeks of the fall
season.
It is a modernized version of the
famous old play, with a musical
score by the rising young German
composer, Kurt Weil, and in its
skillful combination of the best of
the old world with the bright wit of
the new, it is truly one of the year's
unusual pictures.
Aeroplane Journey

On the same bill, Lowell Thomas, noted globe trotter for The Literary Digest, takes us on a thrilling
aeroplane journey in a fascinating
film record of true adventure,
Wings Over The Andes. From beginning to end it is a great show.
And, by the way, have you heard
of the girl whot had an extemporaneous complexion-she made it up
Which goes
as she went along?
with that old song favorite:
"Orange Juice Sorry That You
Made Me Cry?"

Maya Club In Rowland

Behind the doors of the Maya
Club, located on the top floor of
Rowland Hall, there is the largest
colection of Maya documents and
manuscripts in the world, as well
as countless maps and photographs pertaining to the subject
of Maya culture.
When Dr. Gates first started
his research he was faced with
almost a sheer stone wall, for
there was little or no work on the
subject at the time he began his
investigations. The only sources
from which he could gather material for his investigation, were
the monuments and temples scattered throughout Yucatan and
Guatemala, which bore pictographs and hieroglyhics and a
few manuscripts, which the Spanish invaders took back to Europe
with them, as souvenirs. It took
years of constant alertness and
study to collect these sources together, but at last Dr. Gates and
the Maya society have in their
possession, over one-half of all the
original Mayan manuscripts as yet
discovered, as well as photostatic
copies of nearly all the rest.
Cipher Elusive
Even with this huge amount of
reference and data, it has been no
easy job to decipher any of the
glyphs, for there has been no key
found that forms a cipher for all of
them, it was said the vast amount
of knowledge that Dr. Gate has
required has been as a reuslt of
long and patient methods, which
involved classification, indexing
and cross-indexing.

It haunted clerks
for generations
"The first of the month" used to be a time of
feverish activity for ledger clerks. But the Bell
System accounting staff - breaking away from
tradition -simplified the keeping of accounts and
rendering of monthly statements to customers.
They applied a modern system of rotation billing to the telephone business which now spreads
this work evenly throughout the month. In cooperation with manufacturers, they devised special
typewriters and bookkeeping machines. Thus
they did away with inefficient rush and achieved
greater accuracy, speed and neatness.
This is but one example of a point of view found
throughout the Bell System. Even long accepted
routine is constantly studied- it's always worth
looking for the more efficient way!

rial. Most of the brilliant performers of last year are gone. In fact,

DR. RAY VAN ORMAN

"FOUR HORSEMEN"
SCORE VICTORY FOR
JAY HARRIERS, 19-37

Hopkins Losses Less

Hopkins did not suffer so much
this year from the loss of veteran
material. In fact, with the exception of ex-Captain Helm, Bialosworske, and Bill Weitzel, all men
returned for the present campaign.
Thus the Jays have had a good
chance to develop a potential team.
However, certain obstacles did
confront Coach Van Orman which
later proved a severe handicap. In
the first place, the team was affected
by injuries. Throughout the season various varsity members were
either temporarily or permanently
disabled. Included among the injured were Triplett, Ives, Berger,
and several reserves.
As a result, the morale of the
team was broken down considerably. Perhaps this factor alone
might explain the meagre performances that the Jays have been giving in the last few games.
At present, however, the squad is
in an excellent mental state. The
spirit infused by the oncoming tussle and the smooth functioning of
the varsity in its practice sessions
have aided considerably. Especially
those new trick plays that the coach
has up his sleeve have been clicking
well.

Furst, Holtzman, King, And
Packard Take Early
Lead
With the "Four Horsemen" of the
cross-country team in the lead, the
Hopkins harriers defeated the Haverford squad last week, 19-37.
Furst, Holtzman, King, and Packard took the lead from the first and
never relinquished it. They all
crossed the finish line at the same
time.
Successful Season

This year has been one of the
most successful cross-country seasons, the Blue Jays having triumphed in all of their meets except
that with University of Virginia.
After opening the season with a
brilliant victory over Dickinson
College, the Black and Blue squad
lost its meet to Virginia, 21-37.
Fast Race

Running one of the fastest races
ever run on the five-mile course at
St. John's College, the team defeated the Johnnies by the score of
27-28.
The order of the finish in the
Haverford meet was:
King, Hopkins
Furst, Hopkins
Packard, Hopkins
Holtzman, Hopkins
Bodine, Haverford
Vance, Haverford
Mechling, Haverford
Scattergood, Haverford
Brown, Hopkins
Cornman, Hopkins

Four Hopkins Seniors To End
Football Careers At Stadium

Simultaneously with the closing
of the Hopkins football season at
the stadium Thursday, the careers of
four Blue Jay varsity football players will come to an end.
These seniors who will sport their
gridiron togs for the last time
Thursday are Paul Berger, Bill
Reid, Neil Sigler, and Bill Triplett.
Berger Injured

Paul Berger was a regular tackle
on the Black and Blue team this
year until be tore several ligaments
in his leg in the game against
Swarthmore and was forced to retire for the season. He has been
playing football for Hopkins for the
past three seasons. In his first and
second seasons Berger was a substitute lineman. This season, however,
he developed into a regular tackle
and was considered one of the best
linemen in the state prior to his injury.

Although the date

tation of the medal which Dr.
Kent R. Greenfield is to receive
from the Italian government is
yet uncertain, a description of the
medal has been obtained. The
medal bears on the reverse side
the head of the goddess Roma
while on the obverse side Romulus
and Remus are represented. It is
suspended from a ribbon made in
th Italian colors.
Dr. Mario Carosi, the Royal
Italian Consul, recommended Dr.
Greenfield for the honor in recognition of his work in bringing out
the merits of Italian culture. Dr.
Cams said that he had recommended Dr. Greenfield (who is at
present professor of modern
European history at the Hopkins) because of the latter's great
interest in the work over a period
of years. Dr. Carosi also said that
he felt honored to have been able
to recommend Dr. Greenfield.

Berger he has played almost regularly.

Featuring Joe Sanders and his
Original Nighthawks, the First Cotillion will be held at the Alcazar on
Thanksgiving night with Miss Elizabeth Campbell Young, debutante
daughter of Dr. Hugh H. Young,
clinical professor of urology at the
Johns Hopkins School of Medicine,
as the guest of honor.
Under the leadership of Jerome
Toohey, the Cotillion Board has arranged a program that is said to be
the most elaborate ever presented
at a function under the sponsorship
of the university. The entire Alcazar has been taken over for the
affair.
Group Boxes Offered

Dancing, which starts at 10 p. m.,
will be in the main ballroom. The
Blue Room is to be furnished with
soft lights, deep chairs, and thick
rugs. Tables will be placed in the
gymnasium, and ginger-ale, fruit
punch, cracked-ice, and coffee will
be served at nominal charges.
As previously announced, separate boxes will be offered to any
groups or fraternity represented by
a sufficient number of members.
The Grand March which will
start at 11.30, will be led by Jerome
Toohey and Miss Young. At its conclusion, flowers will be presented to
the guest of honor.
It is rumored that, after the presentation of the flowers a special
entertainment will be given by several out-of-town debutantes. Specific plans could not be learned but
something very unusual is hinted.
Dancing will then be resumed, continuing until 3 a. m.

Allardyce Nicoll To
Talk On Kenelm
Digby,Nov.29
Allardyce Nicoll, professor of
English language and literature in
the University of London, will deliver the eleventh annual public lecture of the Tudor and Stuart Literary Club of the Johns Hopkins
University, on November 29, at 5
o'clock in the Great Hall of Levering.
His subject will be "Kenelm
Digby, Poet, Philosopher, and Pirate". Digby was a swashbuckling
cavalier of the time of Raleigh and
"Good Queen Bess."

To Visit Colleges In Northern and Southern
States
FROSH-SOPH DEBATE
SCHEDULED DEC. 8
Final Teams And Topics
To Be Announced
Soon
Canceling the proposed debate
with Oxford, due to the expense
which it would entail, the debating
association has announced that it intends taking two trips, one north and
one south during the spring semester, debating colleges in those regions.
Members of the association believed that, instead of expending a
large sum of money for only one
debate, much more advantage would
be derived from the two trips. It
is planned to make the northern trip
cover New England and New York,
while the southern one will include
Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee.
Each of the journeys will extend
over a period of one week, stops
being made every other night at
colleges en route.

Popular Lecturer

Professor Nicoll is giving a series
of lectures in this country and will
visit Baltimore after a western tour.
He will speak in various colleges in
the South after he leaves here.
He was chosen as the G. A. Clark
Scholar in English Literature. He
was also a lecturer at Longborough
College in English Literature before
he received his professorship.
